I was never in my depth with the science in this book. Not once. But Watson so powerfully captures the humanity of what was going on in the months leading up to the discovery of the structure of DNA that I was swept up in the story even as its facts flew over my head.Here’s what I mean “… we only wished to establish that at least one specific two-chain complementary helix was stereochemically possible. Until this was clear, the objection could be raised that, although our idea was aesthetically elegant, the shape of the sugar-phosphate backbone might not permit its existence. Happily, now we knew that this was not true, and so we had lunch, telling each other that a structure this pretty just had to exist.”My eyes filled with tears near the end as one collaborator after another looked at the model, checked the math, reviewed the chemistry and confirmed what he and his partners had done. I felt the magnitude of it.Watson was one of three scientists awarded the Nobel Prize for the discovery. He was 25 in 1953 when the structure was announced to the scientific world. This memoir was published about 15 years later, but it breathes the life of the younger man, from every boarding house or pub lunch to the breaks from chemical bonds to attend a party that was sure to attract all the international au pairs. Early in the book he takes science off its pedestal and sets it firmly on the ground. “One could not be a successful scientist without realizing that, in contrast to the popular conception supported by newspapers and mothers of scientists, a goodly number of scientists are not only narrow-minded and dull, but also just stupid.”And I was comforted as he read some early findings from another American working on the same problem. “Most of the language was above me, and so I could only get a general impression of his argument. I had no way of judging whether it made sense. The only thing I was sure of was that it was written with style.”He speaks often of the beauty he anticipated in the structure. It would never have occurred to me to describe it that way. I was fascinated, too, that the work was split between theory and equations and the literal, physical construction of the proposed structure. I could picture him – short American hair grown out into a floppy, European look – bent over the metal discs and spheres, manipulating one way, then another, determined to find the position that would hold them all in perfect order.He also speaks of a kind of meditation that bordered on obsession. It would distract him from girls, meals and sleep. Even moments not actively devoted to the question ended up feeding it: “I went ahead spending most evenings at the films, vaguely dreaming that any moment the answer would suddenly hit me.”At some point, I started noting the specific fields involved in (and impacted by) this discovery. Biology and math and genetics I could have anticipated, but then I wrote down specialties such as quantum mechanics, nucleic-acid biochemistry, and theoretical structural chemistry.To me, Watson’s account feels generously inclusive, naming scientist after scientist who contributed an answer to a question or a piece of research. He states in the beginning, in fact, that he would personally credit the discovery to five people, not just the three who received the prize. I’ve learned not everyone shares my opinion of his inclusiveness – and he seems to almost anticipate that in his opening words, acknowledging that any process over such a long time, involving so many people and so much work, is bound to be reported differently from various perspectives. I’m not qualified to give the definitive word, but I didn’t walk away feeling that he’d done this single-handedly or even with only the help of his fellow prize-winners.Don’t get bogged down by the paragraphs you don’t understand. I tried to reread them and despaired. You can appreciate the pursuit and the feat without grasping the details. I did.

A Scientist and A Writer	The Double Helix by James Watson is a well-written, informative autobiography about the lifelong workings of scientist James Watson and his partner, Francis Crick, in discovering the structure of deoxyribonucleic acid — more commonly known as DNA. James Watson’s and Francis Crick’s discovery was revolutionary to the scientific community. By discovering the double helix nature of all DNA molecules, it provided a gateway into further learning and understanding a myriad of important biological process such DNA replication, RNA replication, and protein production. In addition, the discovery allowed for an increase in understanding about the behavior of virus and infections. As a result, through research and development, scientists are able to create antibiotics and antiviral injections to improve human life. Therefore, Watson and Crick’s one discovery created a pathway for many discoveries. 	In cell biology, the central focus is DNA as everything always stems back to one’s DNA. Even though Watson is credited to for his work on discovering the DNA, his name is mentioned for a minute or two. Intrigued to learn more about his experiments, I decided to read his autobiography. After reading the book, James Watson does more than just recount the facts leading to the discovery. Through the use of his first-person narrator, he tells personal stories of the people he encountered and collaborated with. He shows the frustration and tedious work within all his trials. His thoughts and reasoning behind certain observations were made. Thus, as a reader, I was able to engage in the book and feel angry when Watson was angry or excited when an experiment had promising results. Additionally, it highlighted a major theme of success and failure. Every time, Watson and Crick endured a setback, they preserved until they reached a success. This concept of perseverance and success is important to young adults as they enter a world where failures and setbacks are inevitable. Overall, his autobiography was not a book filled with scientific jargon. Instead, it was a story with an actual plot, which made it more interesting. 	However, although the main focus of The Double Helix is about one of the greatest scientific discoveries, it also talks about a major scientific controversy. Watson talks about four people that helped him: Maurice Wilkins, Linus Pauling, Francis Crick, and Rosalind Franklin. In the 20th century, Rosalind Franklin was one of the few women working in a male-dominated field. It was her work with an x-ray cryptography that lead Watson and Crick to deduce a final conclusion. Without her knowing, Maurice Wilkins sent Watson and Crick the picture of Rosalind Franklin’s DNA x-ray, which clearly shows the double nature and overall structure of a DNA molecule. Therefore, Watson and Crick quickly learned that their prior structure was wrong. If it wasn’t for Rosalind Franklin, the two scientists would not have gotten the Nobel Prize, which excludes Franklin’s name. In his book, Watson unsympathetically describes Rosalind Frank, saying that “clearly Rosy had to go or be put in her place” when she would not give him what he wanted. In addition, because Rosalind Franklin was the only girl at that time, Watson and his colleagues made fun of her by calling her Rosy, which was demeaning. Watson carries this nickname into his book, thus showing the stereotypical behavior Rosalind endured. During this chapter of the book, the major theme of stereotyping against women in science in the 20th century was highlighted Overall, I would highly recommend this book who is fascinated by the subject of biology. Not only does it explain the science behind one of the greatest scientific discoveries of all time, it tells a story; one that is characterized by failures, successes, and stereotyping.

As one of the most famous contributors to the biological sciences, you cannot read one biology textbook without learning about the Watson and Crick model. But, we don’t get the full story of how James Watson and Watson Crick determined the structure of DNA. Through their many tumults and endeavors, and even with the help of Rosalind Franklin’s X-ray diffraction of DNA to which she wasn’t given enough credit to, they eventually solved the mystery that codes all life.	The Double Helix is written and told through the eyes of American scientist James Watson where we get his perspective of his personal recollection of the discovery of the structure of DNA. He basically explains his journey from a little bit before his arrive in Cambridge, Massachusetts in 1953, through his journey in collaboration with Francis Crick, to eventually the validation of their famous Watson and Crick model in 1953 where Watson, Crick, and another scientist named maurice Wilkins received the Nobel Prize in Medicine in 1962.	The book is structured and organized into Walston’s account from the intertwinement of letters and memories that reflect his thoughts. Watson chronologically shows the reader the process of how the structure of DNA was discovered and his partner relationship with Crick. He shows how science is discovered and studied through a human perspective instead of only from a factual standpoint. In fact, the terminology used in the book as well as the scientific comparisons are thoroughly explained and put into simpler terms for every audience to understand. Watson’s narrative illustrates how the science discoveries and long periods of research affect personal life. In fact, there are often shifts between the information of how each piece of the puzzle relates to the structure of DNA and the social/background lives of researchers.	Even though Watson mentioned some contributions from other scientists and their backgrounds, I felt as if he didn’t focus on how they were heavily involved. When it comes to these tremendous discoveries of science, we often see competition and separation which is exactly what the book shows. Although there were many characters working on this project, after it's DNA structure verification, Watson only emphasized himself and Cric as well as Wilkins. I was deeply disappointed how little he mentioned of Rosalind Franklin whose x-ray diffraction picture of the double helix was the major catalyst for the final determination of DNA’s structure. He often made sexist and controversial comments about her which I didn't like at all, discrediting her major contribution to science for she didn't receive a Nobel Prize. He often paints her as uncooperative and sour. This led me to kind of decreasingly like the book. Watson’s ego and arrogance shined through and his tone became proud.	Watson did successfully ensnare the reader into the dramatic events that led up to the discovery of DNA’s double helix structure; however, the problem was the drama that I felt like was created by himself. Gossip, pettiness, and misogyny take the wheel in this personal account of how the double helix structure of DNA was discovered, and I expected a more of a respectful, fortunate attitude from Watson. But, in the end, he just made it sound like it was all him and Crick. He owes a better recollection to Rosalind Franklin that was the main contributor to this tremendous discovery. Her years of working with radiation for this discovery cost her life, thus it should be honored.FN

Let’s get this straight: James Watson is a shitty human being. Not even counting the racist and eugenist comments that disgraced him in later life - as portrayed in this book, he’s a sexist, privileged dilletante. He’s a real dick. And considering the fact that he’s a mid-century male in the inequitable field of academia, he’s true to type.Yet reading it again feels like having a conversation with 11th-grade me. That’s when I saw the BBC adaptation, with Jeff Goldblum as Watson, and that’s when I read this book for the first time. I was obsessed. I hung paper double helixes in my locker and signed “Watson and Crick are COOL” in my yearbook. I dreamt of being a famous scientist who burned with the desire to make a discovery.I cracked it open again (actually, listened to the audiobook), because I needed a story of an exciting scientific discovery in the era of coronavirus, where it feels like science can’t move fast enough. And I see why 11th-grade me loved it. The discovery itself is thrilling. The science is action-packed and inspired, not just egghead stuff. Sure I’d like to play with models and talk passionately with friends and make history along the way. Who knew science could be so dramatic? The discovery of the double helix is a story of obsession, competition and drive, with a touch of chance that gives it a certain beautiful sense of meant-to-be. It’s a story of people who, while shitty, are brilliant. When not thinking of sex and tennis, they are thinking about big problems in mad flashes of inspiration and passion. Even though someone like me (female, not white) would never be included in the circles described in this book, it was a part of my personal dysfunction that I loved the images of these nerdy but jocular clubs for brilliant people - brilliant men in backrooms and the charming women who were charismatic enough to enthrall them. I had trouble feeling like I belonged, so ironically I was drawn to an ethic with a rigid or elite definition of belonging - geniuses, intellectuals, artists. I dreamt about being worthy enough to find a place in their ranks and having external validation that I was good enough. The tension with Rosalind Franklin adds to the dramatic tension - data versus theory and the clash of personalities. Then I only saw the drama. Now I see that Watson’s comments on Franklin are unforgivable. I knew it was sexism at the time, but I didn’t take it seriously enough. I’m sad that I didn’t empathize with Rosalind Franklin; I didn’t allow myself to identify with her. I was fine accepting a world where I was on the sidelines, just as she is on the sidelines of this story. And I’m horrified that I watched this in school. Is this the right message to send to young women interested in science?I’m still in awe of the discovery and the incredibly faulty and human narrative that describes it. It’s ugly - but girlfriend, it’s real. I took my last real science class in high school - I never even approached becoming the brilliant scientist I once dreamed of being. But I still am thrilled by this book because it shows science as a very human and relatable affair. Who gets the credit is not based purely on good work. People are pushed out or not included. Like all matters, it is highly political. Science is supposed to be objective, but this story pops that balloon in a way that resonates, thanks to the polarization around science today. I’m 43 and far from 11th-grade me. And while I no longer idolize these men, I appreciate the way it portrays science, warts and all.

The "Double Helix" is a colorful and informative scientific memoir, with a clear narrative from a clear, singular, and candid viewpoint as though at the time of the discovery. However, this candid viewpoint is in the hands of a fellow who holds the wicked sting of cleverness without the benefit of wisdom, perspective, empathy, or reflection; which is sadly not atypical for when many of us were in our early twenties. As a result of this perspective, it's a book that really demands more context to not be misleading and to do justice to the other participants in the story. For that reason, I'm really glad to have read the "Norton Critical Edition" of the book, which includes the original set of scientific papers from all of the three core groups involved, additional memories of the participants, reviews from the time, and facts about how the book came to be published, all set off with framing essays from a peer of the author. With the papers, the multiple remembrances, and the contents of "The Double Helix" itself, the core scientific questions are clearly explained, though some of the further supplemental details will be unclear to some, for example to those who have forgotten or never learned what Bessel functions are all about.Though the original reviews were maybe over-sampled for the casual reader, they certainly had their insights. For example, one reviewer keenly noted that this was a very atypical for a work of science. The necessary experimental work was already done, and there was also relatively little to do in terms of the theoretical framing to the problem. Instead of a problem, a question, or a muddle, they had a puzzle on their hands, a geometric and chemical puzzle. This fact the central issue is a race to solve a puzzle one factor in making the central narrative an easy read.The events of the main memoir concern two years in the mid-twenties of the author. However, it was published sometime later (when the author was in his forties). I hope the author must have access to some diaries, to be able to access the sensibilities and details of the younger author, and decided to keep as close to those materials as he could for the sake of giving a very accurate view of the author as those events were happening. Otherwise, it's a very unseemly perspective for someone then forty. From my perspective, there is a pervasive sexism that seems unremarked upon in the reviews. It's hard to tell if that is entirely the point of view of the author, or whether he's particularly uncharitable to Rosalind Franklin because of her critiques on his theory while enjoying the company of young women in a rather impersonal way. Either way, it was with some enjoyment that I noted that the acknowledgements of Franklin and Gosling's paper thank Crick, but not Watson, which seems appropriate given the circumstances.Overall, if you just read the core narrative, it's very bracing but you'll surely be misled. With all of the contextual materials, it's now a bit more work but provides a full experience.

The Double Helix (once intended to be titled 'Honest Jim' and 'Base Pairs') is a Nobel Laureate, Dr. James Watson's account of one of the ground breaking discoveries in science. Having read this book after reading Brenda Maddox's 'The Dark Lady of DNA', to come to an appropriate conclusion, as far as the accuracy of this book is concerned, is difficult. This is more a novel than history; though a feast for a non scientific reader, a historian would definitely object to the way one of the most important discoveries in the field of molecular biology and genetics has been retold. This is more a fast paced thriller (which in fact was, with Maurice Wilkins and Rosalind Franklin of King's college, Linus Pauling of CalTech and our boys from Cavendish all trying to have a crack at it) than a history of science. Then, there is the matter of Rosalind Franklin, a prolific x ray cryptographer (dubbed 'Rosy' which the feminist lot find offensive) being discredited of her contribution for the sake. Watson says 'It is quite possible that there are inaccuracies here and there. The portrayal of many might not do justice to their caliber, for i write this as I saw when i was 23.' The words written in the epilogue trying to remedy disregard towards Rosalind and her contribution to elucidation of the structure of DNA probably arise from the need to make the book more acceptable. The book was published in spite of uncompromising opposition from Francis Crick, putting their friendship at risk. Many argue that this book is a symbol of blatant misogyny, painting a monster out of Rosalind, who in a manner has become an icon for feminists. It is very unfortunate that she was not recognized for what she was by many. Yet, that is by no means a reason to not hear out what Watson has to say. At the end of the day it all comes down to Science and the hunger of mankind to uncover it's secrets, of which DNA was a huge chunk from a great puzzle whose solution would open up innumerable applications in the field of medicine later on.  To understand how it all went about, this book is a good place to begin with.

The Double Helix is a personal account of the discovery of the double helical structure of the DNA by one of the co-discoverers, James D. Watson.Watson, his co-collaborator Francis Crick (the senior of the two) alongwith Maurice Wilkins (who was at the same time independently working on the structure of the DNA) were awarded the Noble Prize in Medicine in 1963, for their discovery in 1953.Considering the importance of the discovery on the future of science, it ought to have been a thrilling account, coming from one of the participants. Unfortunately, the book disappoints on many counts.Before getting into the review, we should remember that Watson was barely 25 years old when the discovery was made.Surprisingly for a work of autobiography, the picture that emerges of Watson is that of a flippant, misogynist, careless, lazy person, who just happened to be at the right place at the right time.The portrayal of Rosalind Franklin (who worked with Wilkins), the X-ray crystollagrapher without whose X-ray images of the DNA molecule, the discovery of the helical structure would have been impossible, borders on the disrespectful. That Rosalind believed for a long while that the molecule was not a helix is a different matter.So is the portrayal of Linus Pauling, a brilliant Caltech scientist who was independently working to unravel the structure of the DNA. Pauling is painted as a wolf to be wary of, while it turns out to be pretty opposite.There are pages devoted to the social life of the author, his (absence of) sexual life, food habits and other mundane details that reflects a lack of maturity in handling a subject matter of gravity.By the end of it, one cannot but wonder, if Rosalind was deprived of a deserved Nobel and whether Watson was truly deserving of it. I am sure he was a brilliant scientist and was deserving of the Nobel, but the manner in which the subject matter has been handled, and indeed presented, makes one wonder if it was otherwise.Recommended for aficionados of science.

It's a breezy read, iconoclastic and yes, sexist, and at turns charming in its candor and youthful enthusiasm, intriguing in its machiavellian nature, and annoying in its provincial attitudes. In short, it's an expose and it stepped on some toes. Crick, Watson's chief collaborator, considered it "a betrayal of friendship" (paraphrase). There are serious questions regarding the portrayal of Rosalind Franklin, who is essentially cast as the villain in the piece, that are tempered (albeit inadequately) at the conclusion of the tale. My impression is that Watson's prime directive beyond producing a credible account of his interpretation of the mood and circumstances leading to the discovery of "the secret of life" is that he not commit the cardinal sin of being a bore about it. He is anything but that. I was most surprised by the lack of technical training Watson had, and even Crick to a lesser extent, going in. Their "structural approach" to DNA made this possible, through a technique of model building borrowed from Linus Pauling, who became their foil in the race to the landmark discovery. Watson backfilled gaps in his knowledge as needed, gaining a working proficiency in the fields of organic chemistry and X-ray analysis, for example. There was thus a deeper, philosophical divide between Crick & Watson and Franklin regarding the relative merits of theory and practice in the understanding of DNA. The imperatives for such "backfilling" become apparent at various stages in their search and these manifest themselves in several ingenious ploys used to thwart institutional barriers and to pump experts for information. These negotiations, which are fleshed out by Watson's characterization of the people and circumstances involved, infuse the narrative with an immediacy and sense of purpose that builds to a climax when the final pieces of the puzzle are literally put into place. In this fashion, Watson and Crick's discovery of the structure of DNA emerges as a true tour de force. This, IMHO, redeems the narrative and is why I give it four stars, with the noted caveats. At a minimum I would augment this account with a reading of Rosalind Franklin's Wikipedia page.

An overall light-hearted and amusing read about real-life progress towards a great discovery, alternating between sun, rain and mist, suffused with a modernly classical English air.As Watson was an American, I have expected the absurdity of his presence in the British science community, I.e. the vigorous confidence and anxious air permeated from his words, which only enhances the fun as I could see how his surrounding fellow thought of such an untraditional scientist. It is also within expectation the difficulties rising from several wrong assumptions. The illustrations show an evolution of (modern-seen) nonsense to the model we are using today, which is quite interesting for me.However, the non-pedantic, relatable account of scientist lives took me by surprise, as I’m able to peer into geniuses’ not-so-clever everyday behaviour, common-people mistakes which led to embarrassing moments and straight-forward description of Nobel competition, honestly stating it as an essential propeller towards high-level scientific discoveries. Having won the Nobel prize at age of 24, isn’t it symbolic that he has beaten the giant chemist Linus Pauling?Despite joyful at majority of time, Watson’s comments on Rosy’s being feminist in negative terms is indeed sexist, which made me frown more than a few times throughout the book, but a realistic record of the society view to such female scientists. The epilogue rendered me a great deal more comfortable with his remorseful remark on early misunderstanding with her struggle to equality. As Watson has changed his view, the science community today has transformed in sex equality since Rosy’s bickering 24 year-old Watson.Double Helix is a valuable account. Watson may have been filling his mind with seemingly annoying fantasies about girls and Nobel glory, but the passion to biology is what ultimately made him a forever acknowledge-able figure in the field.

The Double Helix: A Personal Account of the Discovery of the Structure of DNA is written from the point of view of James Watson, one of the key scientists in the discovery of the shape of DNA. DNA is now an extremely important biological item that allows the transfer of genes from generation to generation to occur. Its discovery was not an easy one, as Watson states. Basically, there was a race between James Watson and Francis Crick and other scientists in the world; rivalries between everyone were tight and a huge discovery was stolen from a woman named Rosalind Franklin. The young, fame hungry James Watson was so desperate to discover the structure of DNA that he actually stole information from her. Rosalind, or “Rosy” as the men called her “from a distance”, used X-ray crystallography in order to realize that DNA is shaped in a double helical structure. Previously, Watson and Crick were attempting to build a model of DNA, but there was something missing from it. Watson fails to say that he stole data from Rosalind, and he also fails to mention his misogynistic personality. In fact, he mentioned that if “Rosy” could get her “emotions under control, there would be a good chance that she would really help him”.However, despite this lack of honesty, Watson thoroughly writes this book with a certain eloquence. His word choice is phenomenal and his style of writing, although fairly scientific, is fairly easy for a reader to follow. He is personal and what he writes is interesting, but I do not think it is enough to mask the disrespect toward Rosalind Franklin. Overall, I would recommend this novel to anyone interested in learning more about the discovery of DNA or even if they just appreciate biology in general. However, it is not a good read if neither of those descriptions fit you!

What exactly is science? I guess many of us have a vague idea about it. We have heard a lot about what it is supposed to be. We certainly take it for granted. Almost nobody questions it. But how many of us (non-scientists / mortals) have taken a look behind the curtain? Seen behind the glossy papers, the peer-reviewed journals, into the inner-workings of our favorite tool to be the person who claims to be the one to have the right opinion in an argument?The Double Helix is a short account of the discovery of the structure of DNA by James D. Watson. After Avery's experiment, demonstrating that a virus deposits mostly DNA inside a host bacteria (instead of the previously assumed protein to transmit its genes), you'd guess that it would have been a short road to the conclusion that the key to life lies in DNA. This book shows otherwise. Oftentimes, the scientific process gets (mis)represented as a clean-cut, theory-to practice flowchart. Instead of the tinkering, "let's try and see what happens"-approach that really gets you the result. I can wholeheartedly recommend this book to get a lasting impression otherwise. Watson seems eager to rub one in on competitors, his ego and zeal not allowing anyone else to steal what could be his accomplishment. Instead of the detached and focused researcher, it paints a picture of a young man, caught by the want for success, interest in women and maybe a little bit of earnest curiosity. Apparently, Watson became a controversial figure later in life. As I do not know any details, I'll refrain from making any judgments. But do beware that these are the thoughts of a successful young man, who is quite honest about his lust for reputation, acknowledgment and the opposite sex.

An autobiographical account about one of the great discoveries in modern Science. The Double Helix: A Personal Account of the Discovery of the Structure of DNA by James D. Watson. The book details the story of the discovery of the structure of DNA, as well as the personalities, conflicts and controversy surrounding their work, and includes many of his private emotional impressions at the time. In 1953, Watson co-authored with Francis Crick the academic paper proposing the double helix structure of the DNA molecule. Watson, Crick and Maurice Wilkins were awarded the 1962 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine "for their discoveries concerning the molecular structure of nucleic acids and its significance for information transfer in living material". The personal narrative gives you a bird's eye view of the process. A book of its time, does have some cringe worthy moments when talking about "Rossie" the one female scientist involved with the research and her "pretty" pictures. The one lady being Rosalind Elsie Franklin (1920 - 1958) an English chemist and X-ray crystallographer whose work was central to the understanding of the molecular structures of DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid), RNA (ribonucleic acid), viruses, coal, and graphite. Although her works on coal and viruses were appreciated in her lifetime, her contributions to the discovery of the structure of DNA were largely recognised posthumously but it was the early 1950s so what you going to do. Watson does give her moving praise in the epilogue, almost like he was trying to set the recored straight. From a scientific point of view the book is very interesting as it gives you the human story behind this magnificent discovery which really did revolutionize modern science.

Ah! the Great Discovery of DNA in 1953. 18 mo from meeting Francis Crick to solving the DNA puzzle, this maniac egocentric's tale of deceit and humility is one for the history books. Out of The Cavendish, The Discovery. In the thick of the race to break the genetic code between Cal Tech's Linus Pualing, founder of the a-helix and B-sheet secondary structure of acids and the Cavendish Lab of Watson and Associates. From early on, 23 yo James knew the secret to life was close to being unraveled. Hershey's experiments on phage transformation suggested that a single, simple molecule of DNA unbeileivably determines the nature of all species. Physicist turned biologist out of fear of nuclear disaster, Francis Crick flooded the halls of the Cavendish with impotent elation at holding the secret of life, postulated from Pauling's helical mastery of the collagen triple helix and the helix in general, the fundamental shape of wet proteins. Rosy Franklin's King's College lab was the only one east of the Missisipi to be putting forth any significant effort to the discovery. Painstakingly extracting DNA out of cow thymus is different experimental conditions, Rosy spent years calculating bond distances from X-ray crystallographs. Upon finding a particular crystallography of partially hydrated DNA, a striking symmetric reflection appeared, one we are all too familiar with today. Though she died before the Nobel awards were given, Rosy earns her right the most brilliant woman in science since Madame Curie's play on radiation. Jerry Donohue, celebrity structural chemist who demanded the key finding that purine and pyrimidine can only exist in the keto tautomer and not enol, did not receive Nobel credit for his work. "Rosy's difficulties with Maurice and Randall were constructed with her understandable need for being equal to the people she worked with" (124). Rosy's X-ray work at Kings' is increasingly regarded as superb: the sorting out of the A and B forms, by itself would have made her reputation; the phosphate backbone; and helical construction of the tobacco mosaic virus halfway out of the century.

A word of warning; if you approach this book hoping for detailed technical discussion on solving the structure of DNA you're in for a disappointment. There is a real lack of detail on the technical aspects of the work while there is much more detail on the social and personal aspects of the work. Another word of warning - anyone under the slightest illusion that scientist are all liberal folks with progressive attitudes prepare to have those illusions shattered. The belated "apologia" tagged on to the end of the book aside Watson and Crick come across as very sexist particularly in regards to the comments and attitudes displayed towards Rosalind Franklin, although the patronising attitude shown by Watson towards his sister vis a vis her love life and finding the "right" boyfriend / husband is cringe worthy. Setting the sexism aside the arrogance and the overly aggressive competitive attitude is unlikely to endear the dreadful duo to anyone. The overall impression I was left with of Crick was of an egotistical, irritating, patronising oik whose one saving grace was that he was smart. Watson comes across as a lazy intellectual freeloader with an eye for the main chance. I get the impression that the overriding motivation behind Watson and Cricks work was to feed their overweening ambitions and preen their egos. Having said all that the book is a fun roller-coaster ride of the up's and downs involved in the race to solve the structure of DNA - a race that was sadly won by Watson and Crick (I can only lament the fact that it wasn't Pauling or Franklin and Gosling)

The book is a personal account of the events that centred around the discovery of the structure of DNA. I'm not sure why no Hollywood director has yet approached Cumberbatch for the role of Crick - you couldn't get a better science drama!The writing was by no means exemplary; then again neither is Watson a writer nor is the book a literary gem. Yes, Rosalind didn't get enough credit for her work, but neither does it mean she should have been the co-discoverer.Maybe I'll change my views after reading the aforementioned book.

Watson's racial politics aside, and taking into account that Watson did not give any credit to Rosalind Franklin, who was at least as important to the "discovery " process as either Watson himself or his (male) colleague Francis Crick, this is a useful - if partial - book for understanding one aspect of 20th century genetic science. Subsequent developments and writing about these development in the realm of genetics and genomics help to frame this work and point up Watson's limitations and his misdirected race and gender biases. It's a relatively quick read, although given Watsons' recent ill-conceived statements about race-based intelligence and other wrongheaded ideas, you may want to hold your nose while digesting. Incidentally, the stars-based rating system is totally unhelpful for a book like this. I hate the racist vitriol Watson spews and his blatant sexism, but the book itself is helpful as a starting point for learning about DNA. 3 stars seems like a difficult thing to sign in the circumstances, and I understand the objections for those who disagree. I think reading this as a companion to Brenda Maddox's "Rosalind Franklin: Dark Lady of DNA," and/or Rachel Ignotofsky's "Women in Science: 50 Pioneers who Changed the World" can help to ease the strain and broaden one's understanding of what discover actually looks like in science, and who is involved.

One of the greatest scientists of all time (co-discoverer of the form of DNA, as well as subsequent contributions) provides his personal account of the process of discovery. This isn't really a historical account, told by a neutral third party and "objectively" true, but one person's viewpoint, shortly after the discovery (and supported by contemporary notes and artifacts) of his process. What's shocking (even though I know it is near-universal) is just how serendipitous the discovery was, and how critical seemingly meaningless personal and administrative decisions were to the process.Another interesting aspect was the "friendly" state of the (then fallen from importance) UK scientific culture. He contrasts it to the then-recent Manhattan Project and physics of the time, where the true top-tier science was happening, with all artificial impediments forced to the side -- this was instead a field where not stepping on a colleague's toes who had done previous work but wouldn't take it to completion was a serious concern (and in the end, only a US research group run by Linus Pauling put fire underneath them to complete it; without Pauling it's possible DNA wouldn't have been fully characterized for another decade).

Something that has been on my mind a lot over the last year or two has been the skewed perception most people have of how the process of scientific discovery unfolds. Many of us who support science tend to have these romantic views of the scientific method where scientists are these individuals driven solely by a selfless desire to expand the scope of human knowledge. What made this book fantastic was the honest way in which the author lays out the process by which science discovery actually occurs with all the messiness. It's a process driven by not wholly altruistic motives. There's jealousy, self-interest, misogyny, and a whole collection of other emotions that lead to the general forward progression of our understanding of the universe. When we ignore the messiness, as we often do, I think we lose something.I will note that the book definitely contains a fair bit of misogyny. I have noticed that others have tended to count that against the book. For me, that was an important component of the book. The way in which Rosalind Franklin was treated by her peers is an integral part of the historical record and bares acknowledging.

While I still wonder whether he and his buddy F. Crick actually performed any scientific experiment themselves or simply used other scientists results, I am genuinely astonished of how little scientific quality is needed to win a nobel price in medicine. Neither is it his work, nor is James D. Watson anything else than outstandingly lazy and sexist.For a scientist, the revelations in this book are an embarrassment, for an average reader it is a waste of time. Returned it to get at least the money back.

A lot of people who read this book today comment on Watson's misogyny and ethnic prejudice. His treatment of Rosalind Franklin is brutal and is not redeemed by the kind words about her in the epilogue. There isn't much racism, but that's mostly because there are no people of color in the story. In addition to his disdain for women, he takes a few unwarranted potshots at the French and the English. I acknowledge that this part of it shocked me a bit. I want my heroes of science to be good guys all around.And Watson's flaws go beyond social and gender prejudice. He is more than a little arrogant and lazy and is constantly bending the rules. He and Crick were both supposed to be working on other projects. In working on the structure of DNA, they were sneaking around behind the backs of their supervisors. He's not the kind of person that I would pick as a colleague.And yet you have to respect his honesty in telling the story without trying to hide the obvious warts and in giving us an inside view on how a very famous and important scientific discovery happened. And you have to acknowledge the importance of the result.The story told here by Watson strongly supports the theory of how science advances advocated by Paul Feyerabend in "Against Method." It is ad hoc and haphazard, proceeding by fits and starts. They try one method that fails, so they try another and another and then back to the first. It is very unsystematic. And they come to the project with a lot of judgments not yet supported by experiment which they push and push until they manage to bring some colleagues around to their way of thinking with some additional modeling that better fits the facts. You might wish that the project could have run a little more smoothly. But it didn't.

Peyton Gualtieri 	American scientist James Watson wrote the novel The Double Helix to inform and educate his audience of the discovery of the structure of DNA, hence the name “The Double Helix.” He was assisted in his findings by Francis Crick in the Cavendish Laboratory, at Cambridge University. Together they supplied some of the most important information for future experiments and discoveries. And although the novel was published at a later date (1968,) Watson tells his account from a much earlier date, the 1950’s. The most important element of the novel is Watsons motivation to show how science develops from the perspective of scientists. 	I am much more interested in Fictional books, so I would not recommend reading this book if you have a similar liking for fabricated stories. It was definitely interesting to read the accounts of this story from Watson’s perspective;however, it wasn't enough to keep the book in my hands. I would recommend reading the back of the book before, or just wait to have biology in school rather than wasting your time reading this novel. Unless you are a passionate science person, don't read this book.

My favorite part of this is the recollection of Rosalind Franklin's contribution to the discovery of the DNA structure. According to James Watson, the discovery would not have been possible without her immaculate X-ray crystallography data. As a woman in the sciences, I found that very inspiring and I appreciated Watson's apology to Franklin, as he mentioned at the end that he did not give her enough credit. I also loved the way Watson depicted Franklin as a man with a lot of crazy ideas--sort of like someone who would just throw things at a wall to see what sticks. I found that comical and very cool because as researchers I think it is important to keep your curiosity going and not be deterred when an idea doesn't turn out the way you think it should... just come up with another! Apparently the Watson & Crick (& Franklin) DNA structure model stuck to the wall pretty well! Loved reading a first-hand account of this amazing discovery by Watson himself; although it was biased a misogynistic at parts, it was interesting to read his perspective.

I read this book as part of an undergraduate science class a long, long time ago and I just read it again today as I needed to review parts of it for a presentation that I am preparing for work on Hachimoji DNA, a great new invention by unrelated persons, here is a link if you are interested https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hachimo...) All I can say is...three stars for in-your-face (!!!!) This book should be subtitled "Take No Prisoners" or maybe "A Woman Is No Man" (with all respects to Ms Etaf Rum, I loved your new book, it's in my head, I will be reading it again soon!!). If nothing else, this is a must-read for any young woman considering a career in the hard sciences. Dr. Watson puts it all on the page, it's absolutely hilarious except that it's not. His unfounded, complete and utter personal disregard for Dr. Rosalind Franklin, who had a PhD degree and was his colleague (not his junior as he seems to have believed) and had structural biology skills (i.e., was able to generate x-ray crystallographic images) was beyond distasteful. For those of you unfamiliar with x-ray crystallography, this remains an important means to generate information that ultimately leads to a three dimensional image or map of complex molecules. It is an art as well as a science and requires critical hard-won skills and training not only related to generating the crystals, but also interpreting the findings that emerge. If nothing else, read Chapter 2 where Dr. Watson comments disdainfully Dr. Franklin's lack of attention to her wardrobe, cosmetics, and more egregious errors of conduct, mostly related to "not knowing her place." (direct quote from the book). The fact that this book was published in 1968, just a few years after Dr. Franklin's untimely death at age 38 from ovarian cancer, speaks volumes, about what, I almost cannot bear to imagine. If only things were really different now. Sigh. Fast forward to the mid-1980s. My graduate advisor didn't understand why I objected to the demeaning nickname "Little Girl." And so on...

It's not a popular science book, it is a very biased and subjective story about making the discovery of DNA structure.What makes the book interesting is the fact that it was written by James D. Watson, one of the people who received a Nobel prize for this discovery. He is a very controversial person. As many reviewers rightfully noticed, he clearly a sexist and he doesn't even try to be humble while describing his contribution in the work. For me that was the most enjoyable part - to see a scientific breakthrough through the prism of a real person, with his biases, limitations and imperfect character traits. Also the book does a good job in conveying the culture in Cambridge academic circles of that era.In short, if you want to know more about DNA or genome structure - this book is not for you, there are plenty of other good books on that topic. But if you are curious about the academic life and down-to-earth real story of a great discovery - you may enjoy The Double Helix.

It is best to avoid the controversies around this book as much as is possible. I suspect that most of the negative reviews amount to virtue signalling by people who haven't actually read the book. Watson's account of the discovery of the double helix structure of DNA is a memoir, written in memoir form. Watson in this book writes more about the people related to this discovery than about the science of the discovery. He is writing about his personal impressions at the time the events occurred, and so virtually no one, including Watson, comes out with a flattering portrait. The book gives us a good view of the state of biology at the time, with its clashing personalities, rivalries between labs, and rising profile in the public sphere. My main reservation about the book is that Watson is not a very literate writer. The prose is rather bland and he has trouble building a compelling story.

how can such an intelligent man as james watson dedicate such great amounts of his book about the scientific discovery that changed the way we see life to women’s appearance and their inferior role in society? there were some sarcastic comments about women on every other page of this book, and probably the most painful was when he was writing about rosalind franklin’s presentation about her research regarding the DNA, and he wrote something like “i didn’t listen to her, i couldn’t stop thinking about how she might look like if she put some effort into her appearance and put on some makeup”. seriously? i wanted to read a book that would give me more insight into one of the greatest discoveries of the human history, and instead i got a bunch of sexist comments and dry as hell sense of humor. i hate it when people whose minds i admire so much turn out to be pieces of shit.

A fascinating account of the events leading to the discovery of the structure of DNA. The summit of a scientific discovery rests upon the strata of various collaborative work. A better parable is a jigsaw puzzle, to be filled in by gaps left by science in the past and the present. The book also mentions the rigmarole of a scientist's quest for funding and the rigors involved in everyday research. It was also interesting to read about Rosalind Franklin, whose pioneering and grossly under-appreciated work in X-ray diffraction helped solve the helical puzzle. Sadly, she did not live long enough to witness the work being awarded the Nobel prize. This particular edition also contained the personal accounts of the big-shots in molecular biology and genetics- Francis Crick, Linus Pauling and Aaron Klug (the last student of Franklin).

This book belonged to the family friend who owned our house before us. He was very interested in science and I kept several of his science-related books. I think this is the first one I've gotten around to reading.It's very easy to read, and while there are scientific explanations, it doesn't get terribly bogged down by them. The book is also an account of the personalities, politics and interactions that allowed for this discovery.I appreciated how Watson clearly stated right from the beginning that there were contributions from five people. Only three of them got the Nobel for it, though - Rosalind Franklin died before it was awarded (and they apparently don't award them posthumously), and Linus Pauling, though he was on the right track, got soundly beaten to the final line by Watson and Crick.It's a quick and interesting read and I enjoyed it.

My review of this book has nothing the featured science. No, it’s the misogyny that these pages are lousy with. Growing up knowing I wanted to be a scientist, Rosalind Franklin was among my heroes. Her contribution to the discovery of DNA’s structure was essential. She was the one who provided the proof, laid the groundwork. And not only was she not celebrated for her work, the men involved constantly demeaned her because of her personality. They said she was the dark lady of DNA, that she was angry and mercurial. They dismissed and belittled her. She was a brilliant individual. The few paragraphs at the end where a “regretful” Watson says his views were wrong do not make up for the fact that she does not get the credit she deserves. He still published this book, and the text gives her no credit or even kind words. An afterthought is not adequate.

I could not follow. It was really hard not to let my mind stray. Yes, I did have really great information and really cool history, but I had a really hard time reading this book. (Took me 6 days to read, much longer than usual for me!!)Good things:It was super unique and cool to have one of the scientists himself actually write this book. You can really see into their thought process and what they may have felt when they discovered something, etc.There were pictures! I think that having pictures in non-fiction really helps me follow the book more. I can visualize more what the character would be like, etc. 2 stars (Goodreads rating) because it's described as "it's ok" so I did not rate on the number of stars! Recommend for people who are 12 and up.

Interesting first hand account of the discovery of the structure of DNA. Watson provides an insight into the evolution of the research involved during the race to be the first to figure out DNA. The recap of typical scientific discovery - starts and stops, bouncing ideas off colleagues and foes, getting inspiration from totally unrelated projects or conversations, and finally having everything crystallize - was excellent. The overnight a-ha moments rarely happen, typically it's a long slog to get there, and this discovery definitely fits that time frame. Watson, Crick, and Wilkins eventually won a Nobel Prize in 1962 for their discovery. Recommended for history buffs, people who enjoy science, and anyone involved with DNA today.

I really enjoyed this account of the scientist's experience, as a very young man (25 yrs when the DNA structure was identified). I enjoyed that he told the experience from his perspective as an immature, young scientist....with all his biases and foibles. It was interesting to see how competitive the process for scientific discovery and the Nobel Prize can be. I appreciated that he explained the processes in a way that could be understood by a layperson. It was also interesting to see the interaction and influence of various scientists and university research groups upon the understanding of DNA. He expressed his perspective of his experiences throughout the process....and it may be interesting to hear the perspective of others in this scientific circle.

I couldn’t help but think this book must be somewhat of a joke in the beginning.Whether for entertainment purposes for the mass audience, or Watson being genuinely more concerned with the personal lives of his colleagues, the majority of the book just reads as a sexist, juvenile and gossip-y commentary of the behind the scenes race between the American and English labs surrounding the discovery of the DNA structure. Only the last 40 or so pages started to hint at actual science and were interesting. However, for those wanting to gain an intellectual understanding of the thought processes and scientific events leading to the discovery of the DNA structure, this book is a waste of your time.

This was surprisingly readable for a non-scientist like myself. The readability of the text (for the most part-ha! My eyes wiped over a lot of the science, although I do think it was simplified for the average reader) and down-to-earthness of the author inspired me to believe that becoming a Nobel prize winner is something that a regular person with a tenacious spirit and love of science could accomplish. I do think this book would be most appreciated by people who are more science-minded than myself. I appreciated the author's candor, especially as it related to Rosy and to the contributions of so many others who did not ultimately receive credit for the discovery.

I was confused at the careful-- and often condescending-- descriptions James made of his contemporaries, particularly the women around him. He struck me as a selfish, sexist, egotistical man who just barely ekked out a win amongst many, many other capable, brilliant scientists. They were all in pursuit of the same goal: nailing DNA down. Watson (not really Watson, though, because it was Watson, Crick, and Rosalind Franklin, equally) just happened to get there first. Well, to the victor go the spoils, including the book deal. Ironic that his book made me like him less and value his contribution less.

Interesting memoir of the experience of Watson leading up to his and Crick's discovery of the structure of DNA. Watson does come across as a complete jerk, though. And he's also incredibly sexist about women in general and specifically about Rosalind Franklin. Although he does address his hostile portrayal of Franklin in the appendix, and explain why she actually was incredibly important in the discovery of DNA's structure, it almost feels like someone made him add this after the fact. In spite of this, I would recommend this book, since it was short and somewhat interesting (and also for some reason, Watson's portrayal of himself reminded me a bit of Hemingway).

I'm not a scientist but I am familiar with this story and it has always fascinated me. It's a short read and a relatively easy one. It is a clear insight into how science was in the 1950s, a male dominated, often misogynistic, environment, with different research departments competing for various 'prizes'. James Watson's narration seems honest, and "of it's time", but his description of Dr Rosalind Franklin and his dismissive use of the name "Rosy" in his account of her, does not sit well with me. Decent read though, and I might well read more about Rosalind Franklin aka "The Dark Lady of DNA"

This book gets bogged down at the beginning, but last third is pretty thrilling as they unravel the answer to the DNA structure. I always knew Watson was not a very nice man. His views of this undertaking are seldom complimentary to others. Even Francis Crick, his partner, is described more by negative traits. He especially lambasts Rosalind Franklin. In the Epilogue he manages to give her credit, praise her knowledge and achievement and admits to his misjudgment of her. However, he knew this as he wrote the book and could have easily related his impressions then to his later understanding. He might not have come off as such a raging misogynist that way.

An illuminating look into the timeline and nature of a collaborative discovery and the mindset of a young, ambitious scientist. It is a reminder of the fact that science is built upon previous steps and our understanding of a breakthrough does not usually reflect the reality about developing knowledge. I conclude, after reading this book, that there are two types of discoveries- one is the resolution of a major investigation, such as the discovery of DNA's structure or a feasible steam engine, and the other is a paradigm shift, such as relativity, discovery that DNA is the inheritance molecule, etc. I believe that the second type is more worthy of individual praise.

Exceptional passion leading to unraveling the code of life ... It inspires ones to he smart, lively and open minded in one's pursuit for truth and meaning of life. Watsons quirky ways, down to earth attitude and easy going nature helped him achieve it. The journey of dna following thru Watsons life is much more interesting and amusing than the end of story. It's very simply written yet conveys meaning of life to the very core of it, a guide specially for those involved in research. Thrilling, suspenseful. The race among the scientific community to beat another team is presented in the most surreal form thru this book.

So Watson is famously terrible, but this book is actually really interesting. Basically he recreate his search for the double helix structure through reading his old notes and letters home and he comes off as exactly the privileged douche he so clearly is. And it's just interesting to see inside the mind of clever douche on the edge of a great discovery that changed history, built mostly upon the deeper work of other people (as science inevitably is). He was just soooo worried about the fact that Rosalind Franklin had no interest whatsoever in making herself attractive or agreeable for him, HE COULD NOT IMAGINE HOW SHE GAVE NO SHITS ABOUT HIM AT ALL, it's kinda hilarious.

The writing is well done, the science fascinating, the male scientists repugnant. If you can get past that last part, I would recommend the book (anyone who was not a white male was treated like not even a second class citizen, more like a fourth or fifth). The book details the 1953 discovery of the structure of DNA, and it is interesting if you like that kind of thing. Reading about Rosalind Franklin and HER discovery, and the subsequent theft (yes, that is how I see it) of her research is well worth the time.

So! This book is basically a biography of James Watson with a focus on his work with the double helix and journey toward winning the Nobel Prize. If such a subject interests you, you may enjoy this book. I didn't find it entertaining or interesting, although I thought I would. I usually really enjoy biographies and science so... Also, something strange happened. I usually take a great amount of notes when I read, but this one didn't spring about such action. It's freaking me out! How is that possible?

I saw my own self in parts of the story. Time spent in the lab, my dislike for chemistry and my love for scientific curiosity in general. Dr.Watson's way of communicating science and his style of writing, are both brilliant, like himself and his colleagues. It was delightful, reading about the DNA, something that is of much importance to me, something that is going to shape my career and research as I am a biotechnology student, in the voice of the very man who was a part of discovering it. His sense of humor is absolutely wonderful. A must-read for all people having science backgrounds.

Watson's description of the competition to identify DNA is fascinating. About half of this blessedly short memoir is great reading, showing that in the case of DNA, at least, human factors were as influential as the rigorous application of scientific method.The problem with the book is that Watson makes practically no attempt to explain the science. Terminology used by these brilliant young scientists is as alien as can be, unless the reader has a pretty good background in biology and organic chemistry. The story would undoubtedly be even better if there were some sort of a primer.

An interesting biographical account of the events leading up to the discovery of the double helix(DNA). The book seemed a little slow through the the first 2/3rds, but picked up and became a pretty enjoyable read at the end. It was pretty entertaining to read about the race for what is arguably the defining scientific achievement of the 20th century. I had no idea that Linus Pauling played such a huge role in the discovery. I do very much appreciate these kinds of stories about the scientists that make such discoveries, even if it took awhile to get interesting.

My rating has to do with the author. I cannot give a high review to such a man as this author. The majority of the book was him bragging about who he was socializing with and where. His misogynist statements about Rosalind Franklin cannot be condoned and the two page whitewash in his Epilogue is not enough. The science was fascinating, the man not so much. Also, he was admittedly lazy, never seemed to be working very long or very hard and I am surprised he stumbled on to the correct answer.

Story told by James Watson about discovering the structure of DNA. He was an American studying in England in the early 50's and collaborated with a few characters, namely Francis Crick and Maurice Wilkins. This structure of DNA had the attention of many scientists and it was a sort of race to discover the structure. They finally did and received a Nobel prize for their efforts. Lots of focus and effort required to make this discovery. I have heard that an LSD trip inspired them to make the discovery but that was not addressed in the book.

I was beaming at the end of this book. It’s so satisfying that after all the grueling trial-and-errors and academic politics and drama, Crick and Watson arrive at the solution that eventually united everyone. Must mention the important fact though that Rosalind freakin Franklin stood her ground over the idea the phosphate backbone was outside unlike Crick’s and Watson’s presumptions, and her research provided important insight to both men.I give it 3 stars for Watson’s choppy language. I’d had to read sentences over and over to see what he meant.

I think this book was fascinating for many aspects - it shows the ambitious, egotistic and super competitive side of academic researchers, the true nature of scientific progress and the misogyny within the field (it is 1950s though, so hopefully this is more subdued nowadays). The reason for three stars is (I suspect) the translation. I read this book in Turkish and had to re-read every second sentence to be able to understand, especially the scientific parts were completely puzzling (my lack of knowledge in the field of chemistry aside).

Watson was REALLY sexist, but the story he tells is fascinating because it doesn't just illuminate how DNA was determined to be a Double Helix, but gives us a sense of what life was like as a postdoc at Cambridge in the 60s. Watson's attempts to make the book a bildungsroman of sorts places the book in a weird hybrid category of science writing and self-obsessed coming of age novel, which makes for an interesting, if not sometimes appalling, read.

Excellent. There are some tricky technical explanations in here, and they are necessary, for without them there would be no story. An individual view of the close society that academic science is, along with how cheap it was to live in the fifties. In addition time was 'slower' and distance still no barrier to skiing holidays, academic conferences , publication and sharing ideas. Not the space race, but a compelling read all the same.

The discovery of the structure and function of DNA is, undoubtedly, one of the greatest scientific discoveries of the 20th century. Watson’s personal account of the discovery is fascinating, to say the least. Watson’s book also clearly illustrates that there’s no need to be a decent person in order to be a successful scientist. “Honest Jim” has no qualms about putting his pettiness and egomania on full display.

I really liked this book for a few reasons:(1) it provided a behind the scenes perspective into the life in academia(2) it was very raw and allowed (what seemed to be) an unedited view of his experiences(3) one was able to witness the random path to innovation (too often, we are told a fabricated story that has been reverse engineered for the most logical possible narrative - when this was often not the case in reality)

This one was a real struggle to get through. First, the author finishes a chapter on one note and then picks up an entirely different subject in the next. This would be alright if he wasn’t ending each chapter with an indication of continuity. Also, lots of sexism. I picked up this book to read about DNA not to hear about how Dr. Rosalind Franklin could have made herself more attractive! Honestly, does the author have no dignity! The book is a complete waste of time.

We are in 1968, Watson is telling us how he and his friend Crick managed to figured out the pretty DNA structure. He is entertaining while speaking his mind sharing all the trouble to get the model done. The whole thing is knitted together with bits of his social life and impressions on Copenhagen and Cambridge. Sometimes it feels like a journal written by a 25 years old rebel eager to crack the secrets of life and to experience it to the hilt. Crick’s "What mad pursuit" complements this book beautifully. But not as pretty DNA.

I probably would have enjoyed this more if the author had been less generally insulting to Rosalind Franklin and if it had been more sciencey than it was - a lot of it was 'I went and had dinner with this person' or 'I played tennis with that person'. I know that it isn't a science book in the traditional sense and that it is more in the style of a biography but it didn't feel like the science sections were as fleshed out as I would have liked them to be.

The scientific process, the trials of discovery, the failures--all extremely fascinating. The book demonstrates the wonder of scientific discovery. However, James Watson is not a lovely human, and his smugness and sexism is almost too much to bare sometimes. Fascinating story, annoying person. Of course, we're allowed to be imperfect, but the way he treated Rosalind Franklin was just flat out wrong.

I recommend this book only to those interested specifically in the discovery of DNA , the process of scientific discovery or simply in the topic of genetics. Although James Watson has tried his best to make it an enjoyable read - and it is if you’re interested - it is certainly not captivating in its linguistics. On the other hand , the story as numerous twists and turns in this great discovery is really fascinating and let’s you understand the true significance in new scientific endeavours.

This is a short book that felt like a very long read. Too much detail and given that we all know how it ends made it a weary read. However, it's a remarkable insight into the reality of brilliance or innovation or achievement. What often to the outsider seems like genius is actually the result of perseverance, many many false starts and sheer hard work by (mostly) ordinary people. In that, I found it incredibly inspiring.

This was very well written, and was super interesting. Although it was a non fiction book, it reads like historical fiction. I really liked how it focused on the journey and every day life of how they reached their discovery, and gave due credit to the many other scientists who contributed to the discovery. It wasn’t ever confusing because of scientific jargon, but was still very factual and fun to read.

It's an interesting read, and gives insight into the discovery of the double helix, and the nature of science in the early 60s. That said, Watson comes across as thoroughly unlikable, pompous and misogynistic. His portrayal of Rosalind Franklin is particularly regretful. I suppose to some extent it's a comment on the time, but Watson's antics in later life lead me to believe it's also a comment on the man himself.

I'm glad I read this, but wouldn't recommend it to anyone without a good chemistry background. Not for beginning high school students--but maybe toward the end of a chemistry course they'd appreciate it. For any science major in college--definitely! I DID NOT know that Watson and Crick solved this through modeling!!! X-ray crystallography supported the helix, but the chemical bonds and base pairing were done with MODELING! Very cool!

A decent readIgnore the feminists crying about this book. This is work is unapologetic about the author’s point of view and uncovers many fascinating stories of the progress towards the DNA structure. Watson, while a genius, was just as human as any one of us, and make the story very relatable and make us the readers feel that we could made this revolutionary discovery, with some luck and persistence of course.

After reading up to page 33 completely lost interest because I could tell it was going to be a long story about one guy who thinks he's the boss and was positioning himself automatically (a deserving ass-hole who thinks the world revolves around him) making everybody else miserable was perfectly okay. It was that moment to bail and pick up another book.

While I was aware of the scientific side of things this was a fascinating look into how the lives of the scientists worked back in the day. Quite different from now I dare say, but definitely interesting. Sexist at places though Watson does acknowledge some of his prejudices at the end and gives Rosalind Franklin the thanks she deserved.

An enjoyable read; the discovery of the structure of DNA was a fascinating and intriguing story. This is despite the blatant misogyny against Rosalind Franklin and her part played in the discovery.5* for the science (I'd suggest having a basic chemistry/physics knowledge), though lost 1* for the misogyny.

I really enjoyed this book. It was entertaining and interesting. It shows he was a real genius and gives you an insight to the difference between the 50's and modern times. I would highly recommend it to anyone although it does require some background knowledge of DNA as the science part can be quite confusing. Loved it!!!

in terms of literary value, “the double helix” is completely worthless, however, in its final moments i realized how sad it was. watson is completely delusional and, in the strangest of ways, i sympathize with him and i pity him. he isn’t redeemed in my mind by any means, but there is certainly the most important possible regard: understanding.

A wonderfully clear description of a gigantic scientific breakthrough, written by one of the men who made the discovery. Watson shares the process by which he and Francis Crick posited and soon discovered the existence of DNA. Easy to read and quite humorous, this book should be a standard all scientists should hold themselves to when sharing difficult concepts with a non-technical audience.

This book was really fascinating, especially as an aspiring geneticist. The descriptions of the discovery and learning Watson's mannerisms really makes it more real. It’s amazing to see how discoveries come about and the people behind those discoveries. After reading this, I really can’t wait to go into genetics.

Interesting look into how new developments in science really happen, and how much trial and error and patience is required.I could grasp most of the basic concepts and could follow generally what was going on, and found it very interesting but is definitely something to re-read after gaining more knowledge in the area of biology, to fully appreciate the science involved.

Such an interesting book, it feels like a very personal and honest account of one of the great moments in history. As such, it is set in the time of it’s occurrence. I found I could get along with the social commentary as well as the scientific commentary, the book would only be half what it is without any one of the two.

Nicely written memoirs. The thing, which began as uncertainty of a student about what scientific problem he is interested in, ended up as an interesting suspense (taking into account, that the ending is known to everybody), about who will succeed in the elucidating of the DNA structure. Besides science, there are curious recollection of life of the english intellectuals of 50s.

Wonderful narrative of how events unfolded, one thing leading to another, continual investigation, (healthy) competitions across Atlantic finally leading to one of the greatest discoveries of all time. Even with the attempt for some damage control in the epilogue, didn't like the portray of Rosalind Franklin and a star off for that.

The Double Helix was interesting and definitely gave a detailed explanation of how Watson and Crick discovered the structure of DNA. I liked that it was humorous in a dry way, but made me laugh on several occasions. All in all, it was good and I enjoyed reading it, even though it was a class assignment.

It is one sided presentation of one of the most important achievement in science. Although a quick read, there are many gaps in narrative. It was not approved by any of the other collaborators and person who had biggest contributions, Rosalind, was sidelined as minor researcher. It highlights how a readable book by a famous researcher can be b*****it.

I love this quote "One could not be a successful scientist without realizing that , in contrast to the popular conception supported by newspapers and mothers of scientists, a goodly number of scientists are not only narrow-minded and dull, but also just stupid."The author made it clear throughout the book why he said that :D

Watch 'The secret of photo 51'Even though told NOT to by several his own colleagues, watson paints Rosalind negatively. They would not have made the breakthrough without HER and she wasn't alive to defend herself when he published this.One of the greatest betrayals in science.

Very short memoir. A little bit of a letdown, thought he would go more into the technical details on how he (James Watson) devised the DNA model. Instead it was more about how he traveled a lot, talked to other scientists, etc.

Found this an interesting read, despite some of Watson's views, which might now be considered as non-pc. It's written in a chatty way, which, even if you're not a scientist, you'll have a good time with. It's not the best book written on the discovery of the structure of the DNA helix, but as an introduction, it's pretty OK.

An easy-to-read narrative book on the discovery of the structure of DNA. The story is fascinating and I would highly recommend supporting material, like the 1987 TV movie 'Life Story', the play 'Photograph 51' by Anna Ziegler, as well as other online reading.

What a painful relief to read Watson's afterthoughtish admission to sexist misapprehension of Rosalind Franklin's character. A fascinating story of interpersonality and essentialist dilettantism in a world of science.

Janes Watson is a fucking asshole and I could not get past how much of a dick he is to every single person mentioned in this book, and how apparent his naked ambition was to climb over every single person to completely underserved fame. Fuck him.
