I just need to begin by saying that some (ok, a lot) of the science in this book goes over my head. I'm pretty sure that that's also the case for most people who read this who don't have a degree in microbiology. However, since I'm reading this book for my biology class, and we've been talking about the basic structure of DNA, there were parts that I actually understood (which made me feel great). Also, even when you don't understand exactly what's going on, you still can get an idea of what's going on because this is a personal account. The author effectively conveys the emotions that were racing through his mind during that time in his life, and that helps the reader understand at least the gist of what's going on. Now that I've given you this incredibly long and possibly boring introduction, I should probably get down to specifics. "The Double Helix" is by James D. Watson. It has 138 pages (at least the version I had did), which is a fairly short read. I completed it in an afternoon, although I had to re=read a few parts to write this report. The story takes place in Europe, specifically England, in the early 1950s. Some of the main characters are: Francis Crick, a boisterous and obnoxious British researcher; James Watson, the quieter and more absent-minded half of the DNA Duo (see what I did there?); Maurice Wilkins, a cautious, long-time researcher of DNA; Rosalind Franklin, the moody and often disagreeable crystallographer for Maurice.The book starts off with Watson in the Alps, after the events of the story have taken place. He sees a researcher who was part of Wilkins' DNA research lab. Expecting a friendly greeting, the researcher just says "How's Honest Jim?" This simple phrase alludes to the fact that Watson and Crick didn't come up with the structure of DNA solely by themselves. They had some help from a lot of people, some of whom didn't get due credit. The story then flashes back to Watson first arriving in Europe, Denmark specifically. He has wanted to study DNA for a while, and has finally got his chance with Dutch scientist Herman Kalckar. However, Kalckar's research on the metabolism of nucleotides fails to inspire interest in Watson. He learns of a lab in England, the Cavendish, that is studying more the structure of DNA than the processes of it's elements. He transfers to England, and begins to dream about the structure of the DNA molecule with fellow researcher Francis Crick. Watson and Crick brainstorm on the structure of DNA, and with advice from Maurice Wilkins, a researcher at King's College who had been pondering the question of DNA for a while. There, they meet Rosalind Franklin, the newest member of Wilkins' lab. She is a crystallographer, and can take pictures of DNA using X-Rays. However, her personality and ideas clash with those of Wilkins, Watson, and Crick. Several months later, Watson and Crick construct a triple-helic-ed DNA model. They call in the King's College team for remarks, but they are disappointed when Franklin points out that the model is chemically impossible. For the next 15 months, they have little interest in DNA. Then, renowned scientist Linus Pauling states that he has discovered the structure of DNA. However, Watson realizes that Pauling has made a mistake. He and Crick work with renewed vigour, knowing that the great scientist will as well to correct his mistake. Finally, using previously recorded data by Erwin Chargaff, and fellow US chemist Donahue, the two build an accurate model representing the structure of DNA. The King's team approves, and they publish simultaneous articles in the magazine "Nature."Something that I like about this book was that the author doesn't try to hide the character's flaws (sometimes including his own). One passage referring to Franklin talks about how she "did something novel with her hair." One of her lectures is described as "without warmth of frivolity" and a passage referring to Crick states that "there existed an unspoken yet real fear of Crick." I would recommend the book to those interested in the personal relationships surrounding the discovery of the structure of DNA. This book really hits home the fact that science isn't all about performing experiments in a lab. Human beings thoughts and emotions need to be considered when you are in a race to make the next big scientific discovery. This book is a very interesting combination of biology, chemistry, physics, and emotion. I really enjoyed the read, and enthusiastically recommend it.

There's definitely a feeling, even noted in an indirect way by Watson, that he didn't really need to rush the discovery - as said before, Pauling was close to it, and arguably most of the hard work had been done by crystallographers and structural chemists long before Watson saw the opportunity.The rest of the book, about the same quantity of focus as given to the actual pursuit, is about Watson attempting to increase his social standing - there are lots of parties and dinners. Mike Adkins“The Double Helix: A Personal Account of the Discovery of the Structure of DNA”By James D. WatsonThe Double Helix: A Personal Account of the Discovery of the Structure of DNA. The title states it all. This book is told from James Watson’s point of view of the discovery of the structure of DNA. The book details the often political nature of the research, as well as the scientists’ personalities, disagreements, and drama surrounding their work. Watson gives us an engaging story and inside look at one of the most significant discoveries of the 20th century.Of special interest is the cutthroat nature and jealous dealings between scientists of different universities working towards a common goal. The Book’s Preface conditions the reader with the line “On the other hand, I do not believe that the way DNA came out constitutes an odd exception to a scientific world complicated by the contradictory pulls of ambition and the sense of fair play.” In the opening narrative Watson relates a comment made to him by a fellow researcher; “But all he said was “How’s Honest Jim?” and quickly increasing his pace was soon below me on the path.” By the end of the book it is clear that the comment was not a compliment. What I liked about this book is Watson’s openness in admitting his own unscrupulous actions and dark side of research. Covertly obtaining others research data, withholding information from colleagues, animated arguments, and the quaint pleasure in watching a competitor’s blunder all play a role in making this book a provocative and fun read.Throughout the book Watson seems to regard Noble Laureate Linus Pauling with a mixture of awe and resentment. Watson views Pauling's achievements in building models of proteins as what Watson hopes to accomplish with DNA. Watson also views Pauling as his main rival and reacts with glee when he discovers a fatal error in Pauling’s flawed triple helix DNA model. Watson realizes that the error will set Pauling’s research back indefinitely. Ethically, Watson should have informed Pauling of the theory’s failings. Did he? Positively no. Instead, Watson used Pauling’s mistake to buy time for his own research. Watson is just about as competitive with his other rivals, Maurice Wilkins and Rosalind Franklin.Watson is candid in that he was not very skilled in the laboratory and had to turn to the crystallography expert Rosalind Franklin to get pictures of the molecule. Rosalind Franklin’s contributions to the discovery of DNA’s structure can’t be overstated. It was Franklin who postulated that the phosphate components are located in the outer part of the molecule. Franklin also determined that the amount of water found in the molecule would be in equilibrium with the cell. These concepts are critical in terms of the stability of the molecule. She also generated the crucial X-ray data showing that the B form of DNA is clearly helical. As you read this book, you'll find that there is significant tension between Watson and Franklin. Watson’s scientific research relied on collaboration with Rosalind Franklin and the ability to share ideas; however Watson depicts Franklin with a certain amount of distain. He is not above intellectual theft and worse, character assassination. What stands out throughout the book is Watson’s determination to understand DNA and his willingness to do whatever it took to be the first to discover its structure. This is not to say that Watson was not an intellectual and gifted scientist in his own right. He did assemble the pieces of the DNA puzzle that others had missed. Overall the book is an fun read that keeps the reader’s attention with interesting character depictions and scientific discovery, but falls short in terms of pacing. While “The Double Helix” is a book about science it highlights the human elements often found in scientific research, 3/5 on good reads

Wow, Watson is kind of an blunt gossip! (Opening sentence of chapter 1: "I have never seen Francis Crick in a modest mood" pg 7.) And so of course I loved reading this book, which is rife with talking behind people's backs. The incredible scientific breakthroughs being made throughout are an added bonus. Watson makes no bones about the personal nature of memory in memoir: "All of these people, should they desire, can indicate events and details they remember differently" (225). I always enjoy reading about the everyday lifestyles of occupations so different from my own: I liked reading 365 Days: A Diary by Julie Doucet to see the daily life of a working artist, and I was delighted by Watson's frank report of the inner workings of his life as a scientists, albeit somewhat unorthodox.I was at first reluctant to read this book because of my perception of Rosalind Franklin getting the shaft for her part in the discovery of DNA structure. My image of the situation was of her getting screwed out of her due credit by "the man," one of whom was James Watson. And this account did nothing to disabuse me of that impression. From the first mention of Franklin on page 16, she is portrayed as a troublesome, meddling, strident feminist man-hater whose sole purpose is to cause trouble ("Clearly Rosy had to go or be put in her place" pg 17.) That Watson spends the closing pages of his book clearing her name (posthumously, I might add) of the vitriol he has spent the rest of the book heaping upon her--well, I would call that a classic case of too little, too late.Some samples:"Of course there were scientists who thought the evidence favoring DNA was inconclusive and preferred to believe that genes were protein molecules...Many were cantankerous old fools who unfailingly backed the wrong horses. One could not be a successful scientist without realizing that, in contrast to the popular conception supported by newspapers and mothers of scientists, a goodly number of scientists are not only narrow-minded and dull, but also just stupid."(14)"Her [Rosalind Franklin] past uncompromising statements on this matter thus reflected first-rate science, not the outpourings of a misguided feminist."(212)"But now I was alone, looking at the long-haired girls near St. Germain des Pres and knowing they were not for me. I was twenty-five and too old to be unusual."(223)"By then all traces of our early bickering were forgotten, and we both came to appreciate greatly her [Rosalind Franklin] personal honesty and generosity, realizing years too late the struggles that the intelligent woman faces to be accepted by a scientific world which often regards women as mere diversions from serious thinking. Rosalind's exemplary courage and integrity were apparent to all when, knowing she was mortally ill, she did not complain but continued working on a high level until a few weeks before her death."(226)

Highly readable and entertaining account of the discovery of the 3-dimensional composition of DNA from the point of view of one of the three recipients of the Nobel prize which resulted from the breakthrough. There is no requirement of the reader to have a scientific background; the book is as much a tale about postgraduate university life and the difficulties of obtaining enough decent food and heat in austere post war England during the 1950s. Interestingly the Cavendish laboratory were trying to get rid of Francis Crick, his professor avoided him as much as possible due to Crick's loud voice and laugh. Watson was scratching around looking for something interesting to stimulate him when he became involved in the race to discover the structure of DNA. Much of the groundwork had been done by others, notably Wilkins and Franklin in King's (London) and Linus Pauling in the USA. Wilkins didn't get on with Rosalind Franklin and their work seemed, to Watson, to be stagnating. Pauling was nearly there having deduced the structure of the alpha helix through sheer brain power and was a genius as well as a force of nature. Watson could sense an opportunity for greatness, if only he could learn enough quickly about the biology and chemistry needed to proceed to making 3-dimensional models of DNA. He attended lectures by Franklin but was terrified of her scorn and couldn't bring himself to ask her the necessary questions, afraid he wouldn't understand her answers about her x-ray crystallography photographs of DNA. Watson taught himself how to perform this and confirmed to his own satisfaction that DNA was helical but they couldn't get the bases to fit together in the models and they had no idea how many strands there were in the helix. It seemed Pauling might hit the answer first but his published paper was flawed and Crick and Watson used the opportunity, and the inside knowledge provided to them by Pauling's son, who happened to be their colleague at Cambridge, to make their model fit perfectly; the key to life turned out to be simple and beautiful. Having been scathing about Rosalind Franklin throughout the book (she rubbished Watson's conviction that DNA was a tightly coiled helix), Watson is very charitable about her contribution to the discovery of the structure of DNA and her subsequent generosity of spirit and co-operation towards her rivals at Cambridge. It would be very interesting to read the accounts of the other protagonists as there remains an indignant irritation at King's that Franklin (who died in her 30s) did not share the Nobel Prize or receive due acknowledgment at the time. Linus Pauling got 2 Nobel Prizes so probably suffered rather less.If you are in Cambridge you can still walk from the old Cavendish laboratory, down Free School Lane to the Eagle pub where Crick and Watson had their lunch 6 days a week and sit at the spot where they announced to anyone who was listening that they had discovered the secret of life itself.

Everything I study in genetics arises from the basic structure of DNA, a much feted discovery that made Watson and Crick synonymous with DNA itself. On the other hand, Watson is (deservedly, in my opinion) considered a racist bigot, who happened to solve one of biology's fundamental puzzles. This made me approach the book with mixed feelings. Once I started, however, there was no stopping. The account, from Watson's point of view, presents him as an irreverent brash American, who is not afraid to state what he thinks, and has his mind set on the bigger picture in biology. In one chapter, he pooh-poohs the idea of his doing 'solid, yet unexciting research' instead of addressing full-on the nature of life itself. It's this uninhibited ambition that leaves a mark throughout the book. When Watson, after a series of positions in labs that didn't quite excite him, found himself in the Cavendish lab at Cambridge, he found an environment and a partner that propelled him towards his goal of discovering the structure of DNA. Watson was always interested in this question. However, politics (overstepping on maurice Wilkins' research) and inexperience (Watson not being a trained crystallographer) had prevented him from making inroads. With Crick's theoretical insights and Wilkins' (and Rosalind Franklin's) experimental data, the solution was within sight, and then reached. This week's New Yorker had a profile of Yitang Zhang, the mathematician who solved the prime number problem of mathematics last year. It led to my wondering what it takes to solve such a problem. Why did this man of all people solve it? Reading the Double Helix, an account of the discovery of another 'Big Question' opened my eyes a little wider. It was Watson's single-minded pursuit of the idea that allowed him to make connections that others didn't.Also fascinating to read was the nature of science in the pre-internet era. Distance meant that a researcher in one continent (Linus Pauling in this case, who was also working on the same problem) had little or no access to data on another continent (Rosalind Franklin's extraordinarily important crystallographic data) unless he happened to be aware of it through personal sources. Watson and Crick were brilliant men, but they were fortunate to be where they were. Rosalind Franklin's story is one of the most tragic in biology, and one that fascinates me. I was curious to see how Watson would present it, considering he has made sexist remarks in the past. He calls her 'Rosy' throughout the book, and at one point remarks on her physical appearance and how she would be presentable were she only to try. As unsavoury as these statements are, he comes around later and acknowledges her integrity, her scientific expertise and her brilliance in an epilogue that comes close to being moving. I would have loved to have read Franklin's account of the same events. One has to do, however, with Watson's account, and it is an engaging and inspiring read. An absolutely essential read for biologists.

An invaluable account of the discovery of the structure of DNA in the early 1950s by one of the co-founders himself. Many have criticized Watson for arrogance, sexism (against Rosalind Franklin), and unscrupulous use of others' scientific research (especially Franklin's), and they certainly have their grounds for doing so. But I'm so immensely grateful that Watson dared publish the sometimes-politically-incorrect views he held during the discovery of DNA's structure. To whitewash the questionable bits would have been to distort reality (the way, for better or worse, it actually happened for one of the five major players involved)--to obscure the characteristic quirks and prejudices that accompanied one of the co-discoverers of DNA in the heat of the hunt. To see things as Watson saw them in the early 50s (for all his misconceptions) is to get magically close to the all-too-human personalities that helped elucidate the gene-bearing structure. Usually these autobiographical details are excised from scientific history as irrelevant and superfluous. This is unfortunate, as it helps bring science history to life. Watson reminds us of the very human context in which great discoveries take place, and the identification of DNA's molecular structure is interspersed with detours about Cambridge drinking parties, Alpine vacations, and bitter rivalries. All the conversations take place "over lunch" or "over coffee" or "at tea." And all the set backs, all the trials an errors are recorded. This is how scientific discovery really happens. The dead ends have not been "edited out."Things may not have happened precisely as Watson recounts, but I don't mind that. Nothing ever happens precisely the way people remember, and as long as we take Watson's account with a grain of salt (as he advises us to do), we're not in danger of conflating his account with the infallible truth. To see the structure of the DNA molecule coming to light from Watson's perspective is breathtaking. Really, this is such a wonderful read (especially the second half, when all of the pieces are nearly together.) Furthermore, this is a narrative of immense historical import, as the discovery of the structure of DNA in '53 initiated perhaps the greatest scientific revolution since Darwin. This narrative has become a useful point of reference for me, helping to orient me in the disorienting currents and countercurrents of 20th-century intellectual history.As a historical document, I give this an unequivocal five stars. (There's simply nothing like it.) As a piece of "creative non-fiction," I give it four stars. Watson is a good writer, though not a great one, and the prose could be tighter a points and less unnecessarily tight at others. That said, he's still a pleasure to read, and the prose can be tremendously humorous at times--especially when he's poking fun at people. I will never forget this book, and look forward to re-reading it in the future. For all its faults, it's already so near to my heart.

James DiPernaMs. Brooks Academic English 10January 7 2013The Double Helix is a personal account of one of the most important biological and scientific discoveries ever uncovered by man. The book is told in the first person by James D. Watson, who along with Francis Crick, discovers ultimately that DNA is in the structure of a double helix. This personal account of James D. Watson allows you to learn about the other completing scientists of the time, and the hard work that James D. Watson and Francis Crick put into this magnificent discovery. The book profiles their early work at Cambridge University, their interactions with other scientists, and their personal thoughts and opinions aside from the straight science of the topic. By reading The Double Helix, the reader gets to experience the discovery of DNA on a personal scale and gets to encounter the trials and tribulations, and ultimately the rewards of one of the greatest scientific discovery of the twentieth century.This book falls into the category memoir in nonfiction. It could, however, also be considered an autobiography. Th reason The Double Helix is a memoir is because it profiles a certain segment of a person's life, told by that particular person, whereas an autobiography is a self-told account of that particular person's entire life. The two main things that lead me to conclude that this work of nonfiction is a memoir are that it is told in the first person point of view, by James D. First of all, I had the honor of meeting the author of this book and taking a picture with him. As the subtitle suggests, this is James Watson narrating the account of the discovery of the structure of DNA: the double helix. The journey of this discovery was basically a heated race between Watson/Crick and a great American chemist named Linus Pauling. Watson and Crick were smart men and curious. That was all it took! They didn't have the background for their discovery, for Watson was set to be a zoologist and Crick was a physicist. However, they learned quickly off from textbooks and enjoyed solving the puzzle. They both contributed to this marveling discovery.Another interesting character involved in this race was Linus Pauling. Pauling was an exceptional chemist who had won the Noble Prize in Chemistry for his discovery of the alpha-helix structure of protein. He was also a pacifist and won the Nobel Peace Prize. This scientist was truly feared by Watson and Crick since they thought he'd beat them to the double helix, which he almost did! However, his experimental data weren't as good as those owned by Watson and Crick. He would have cracked it open, otherwise, and won his third Nobel Prize! A magnificent scientist!Another, rather controversial part of the story, was Rosalind Franklin. Franklin was an expert in X-ray crystallography and she had been taken x-ray images of the DNA. She was very accomplished, but very grumpy and arrogant, too. This made it so hard to work with her in the lab environment. She fundamentally disagreed with Watson and Crick and saw their approach (model-building, influenced by Pauling) as futile and unfit to unravel the structure of the DNA. She actually didn't think it was a helix at all! Watson, Crick, and Maurice Wilkins thus duplicated her experimental data to support their models, but without her permission. However, Watson at the end of the book extensively acknowledges her crucial role in the discovery and praises her and women of science and he criticizes alienating women in the scientific field in general. An interesting read about one of the greatest discoveries in science generally and in molecular biology in particular by probably the greatest biologist living today.

The Double Helix presents the narrow of window in time (1953-1954) just prior to solving the DNA structure when molecular biology was still a new field. I enjoyed Watson's book, particularly his concise perspective on the event leading up to their triumphant discovery. It was interesting to learn that the majority of scientist at the time were largely unaware that DNA was the "transforming principle". As this book points out- although the discovery of the DNA molecular structure was credited to James D. Watson and Francis H.C. Crick, the quest to elucidate the structure of DNA was many years in the making and accomplished through the efforts of many devoted scientist. I read the Norton Critical Edition of the Double Helix that was edited by Gunther S. Stent. This edition includes a series of photos, notes, and a great introduction by along with 13 reprinted reviews by a number of scientific minds that offer views on James D. Watson and commentary on the ethics of scientific discovery. As many reviewers have pointed out, this book is the perspective of one tenacious mind and should not be considered in light of other historical narratives that are available in print. I agree with the reviewers included in the book that the Double Helix will remain a literary achievement apart from its scientific merits. Prior to reading the Double Helix I was vaguely aware of Rosalind Franklin's x-ray work with Maurice Wilkins; however it was only after reading this book that I realized how important x-ray crystallography was to the discovery of the DNA structure and how underappreciated Dr. Franklin's efforts were. I am eager to read Maurice Wilkins book (The Third Man of the Double Helix: The Autobiography of Maurice Wilkins) and at least one of the books dedicated to the contributions Dr. Franklin (Rosalind Franklin: The Dark Lady of DNA & Rosalind Franklin and DNA). Overall, I recommend this book to emerging scientists and self-confessed DNA addicts- the Double Helix is a great piece of literature that illustrates the excitement of discovery and the people who defined molecular biology.

This is a memoir of a Nobel prize-winning Scientist that reads like a cross between a personal autobiography and a detective story. Add the insights into the imagination of one of the greatest scientists of the twentieth century and you have a unique book. I read the book with wonder, delight and puzzlement alternatively as I encountered different aspects of the life of James Watson. He is unafraid to compliment his colleagues and competitors yet is also uncompromising in his criticism of those scientists (Linus Pauling, for example) who are either on the wrong track or just wrong-headed in their ideas or both. I was impressed with his methods which involved serious study combined with leisure activities, tennis being a favorite, that did not seem to detract from his scientific thinking and probably helped his imagination achieve more than it might otherwise have. The book describes a different time, the 1950s, when the "Red scare" was predominant in the United States and Europe (not without reason) to the detriment of the free exchange of scientific ideas (again Linus Pauling is a prominent example in his sufferings at the hand of the United States government). But more importantly it describes the collaboration of two colleagues (Watson & Francis Crick) with very different personal styles of scientific endeavor in their pursuit of the goal of identifying the essential nature of DNA. This includes giving credit to those who provided helpful details that made their discovery possible. Written with a lucid style that put this reader at ease this is one of the best memoirs of any kind that I have read. While there are a number of scientific details and references, they are not terribly difficult to digest and I would particularly recommend this memoir to readers who might otherwise shy away from scientific tomes - Watson makes scientific endeavor the most interesting if not exciting thing in the world.

I cannot believe that I had not read this before. I had been carrying around my father's copy for twenty-five years but only just read it. It is a fascinating, exciting and sometimes even funny account of the race to unravel the structure of DNA. It is unflinchingly honest in describing not only the thrill of scientific discovery but also the more ordinary impulses including scientific rivlaries and everything from the desire to win the Nobel Prize to the desire to win over girls. It is also a great account of collaboration, not only with Francis Crick but also with Maurice Wilkins, Rosalind Franklin, and Linus Pauling -- in the case of the later three the collaboration was mixed with a fervent desire that they not beat Watson and Crick to the discovery of the strucure of DNA. Finally, it is also an excellent detective story as Watson and Crick follow fragmenatory and contradictory evidence along several false leads but eventually stumble on the extremely elegant answer.The Double Helix is at the opposite extreme of Einstein's book Relativity which presents the pure science, derived from first principles, and explained to the lay reader. Instead in The Double Helix, the extensive descriptions of the science are all subsurvient to moving the story of the discovery forward. None of these scientific discsussions are derived from first principles or includes any explanation for the reader (and I, for one, started the book with no knowledge of x-ray crystallography or stereoscopic chemistry and only pieced together a dim understanding of them over the course of the book). And there is virtually no discussion of the implications of the discovery, what followed, or really much in the way of context. But it is hard to hold any of that against The Double Helix, especially when many, many other books have handled all of those topics, while this book uniquely and superlatively describes the process of discovery itself.

I'm glad I read this book. Although it was not as ground-breaking as it could have been, it captured the excitement of making a life-changing discovery (the 'secret to life'). I also enjoyed the personalities attached to people I've learned about in my physics degree, such as Bragg from Bragg's law.I now have a better understanding of DNA, the scientific discovery process and, although not Watson's intention, the struggles of women in science. With regards to the reviews claiming that this book gives a sexist account, I do agree. All of the women mentioned, even Rosalind Franklin, were described extensively by their appearance and were not taken seriously intellectually. If that level of sexism were to not exist in their environment, Franklin's work would have been more respected by her co-workers. Perhaps she wouldn't have felt like she needed to leave, choosing instead to work more closely with Crick and Watson, and maybe this would have ended up with her also winning the Nobel prize.Although it is easy to blame Watson for his portrayal of her, his biases towards women reflected those of everyone around him. His acknowledgement of this sexism in the epilogue shows that, to some extent, he must have chosen to depict Franklin in this demeaning way. I strangely appreciate this, since he does not dishonour her by ignoring her struggles and changing the story retrospectively. However, it is unlikely that he underwent the deep self-reflection necessary to fully combat his biases.It is a great shame that women such as Rosalind Franklin had to face discrimination and be regarded as tough and brash in her attempt to be seen as an equal. From my personal experience with physics, this is still a significant problem today. There are many more measures in place to prevent it, but sexism still thrives and affects every woman in the field.

The novel Double Helix by James D. Watson documents the discovery of the shape and importance of the DNA molecule in a first person narrative. It shows the turbulent politics of science in the mid 20th century and how discoveries are made not through forward logical thinking, but a combination of all sorts of factors, the human and emotional element not being the least of which. It details how Watson and Crick use crystallography to determine possibilities for the shape of DNA. It was a new idea at the time for any serious scientist to think that DNA held any importance to genetics, the dominant thought at the time being that proteins were at the root of genes.	This novel is a great insight into how science is conducted in the real world. It gives the reader a look into the clash of culture, emotion, and personality that is often prevalent in different scientific fields. It shows how messy science can get and how it is not nearly as straight forward or “boring” as many in the media would have you believe. It is full of turmoil, politics, social gatherings, and culture, but at it's heart it is still all about determining how the universe works through the use of experimentation and testable hypotheses.	The Double Helix shows that in order to be a great scientist you do not need to know everything by memory or have the capacity to understand every rule and principle there is to know. Instead, it takes determination, willpower, plenty of knowledge, but also a sense of wonder that keeps you thinking and always questioning. In addition, it shows that there is always something further to learn, that if you somehow run out of questions to ask, then you simply aren't looking hard enough.

For most people, the discovery of the double-helix structure of DNA is the kind of ninth grade science fact you forgot as soon as the final was over. But the real story behind the breakthrough is a lot more interesting than trying to remember which of the bases pair up – and in The Double Helix, DNA-discoverer James D. Watson shares his memories of the find that earned him and his research partner, Francis Crick, a Nobel Prize.Watson was in his early 20s. He and Crick raced frantically against other researchers – most notably Linus Pauling – in an effort to illuminate the structure of DNA, and thereby shed light on the genetics of all life. Watson doesn't shy away from using scientific terms, but Gardner's straightforward reading makes even the most complicated experiments easy to follow. Gardner gives Watson's voice all the excitement, passion, and dedication you'd expect from a young scientist on the verge of one of the world's greatest discoveries.Roger Clark lends his elegant tenor to the book's afterward, written by Sir Lawrence Bragg --the youngest Nobel winner in history - who offers a scientist's take on Watson's memories. Bragg points out that The Double Helix is a record of "impressions, not facts" but he gets to the heart of what makes this memoir so appealing.I enjoyed the down-to-earth telling of his thoughts. I was surprised to learn that men we think of in such great terms shirked work they don't like, avoid areas they didn't want to learn, and fought and fussed with their peers. At least in Watson's memories, there was a lot of play in addition to work. It seems that play and interaction with others is the stimulus that prompts the "a ha" moments.

I was originally going to deduct a star for James Watson's one sided, rather sexist, portrayal of Rosalind Franklin (or 'Rosy', as he refers to her in the book, as they did behind her back in the early 50's when this all took place) but Watson makes it clear from the outset that he wanted to write the book as an honest portrayal of his own personal viewpoint during the lead up to his and Francis Crick's discovery of the 3D structure of DNA and to not write a definitive and objective tome on the whole matter (stating more than once that other people involved may remember certain events differently). And candid and subjective it is. We'd be kidding ourselves if we thought males of the 1950's weren't a sexist bunch, so in the end I believe Watson deserves kudos for being honest about his sometimes unflattering impressions of people (both male and female) during the 1951-53 time frame covered in this book, even though his feelings for the person may have changed later on. The final 2 paragraphs in the epilogue are solely about Rosalind Franklin (who died 10 years prior to this book being published) and how that after the double helix discovery he came to realise that his "initial impressions of her, both scientific and personal [...], were often wrong."Overall The Double Helix is a quick and enjoyable read about James Watson and the three years of his life that lead to one of the greatest scientific discoveries of the 20th century. A new edition has just been published with a lot of extra content (letters and such) and I think I'll have to track down a copy to add to my library next to the old and dog-eared 2nd hand copy that I just finished.
